messages.message: If it's a common component, how about putting in `shared/components/OverflowText`? This will make it more visible and more likely to be reused

I like our pattern of using an `S` prefix to denote styled components that have no business logic or component composition in them - makes it easier to tell what you're working with when you see the styled components being used

Makes sense, so `shared/components/SOverflowText`? If we put it in styles, only thought is that it may not be visible so people will keep making their own version (similar to clamp/truncate currently)

Does that really make it that much more visible though? I look at these the same way I would look at functions in StrUtils - I wouldn't want to make each of those utils a separate file, and I know that if I want to manipulate a string, my first stop to see if the function already exists would be that file.

Hmm ok, maybe I'm looking at (~`shared/component/styles`~) `shared/styles` incorrectly on what it will store. If it will store these reusable styled components then it makes sense to look over there first.
I thought it would be mainly storing the styles of other shared components (causing it hard to find shared global components), but that can live inside the component's folder (`shared/components/Component/styles.ts`) instead of the shared styles.

Oh I was thinking it wouldn't be nested in the `components` folder, there would be a `shared/styles` folder that holds reusable styled components. So all the text-related ones (so far I have `SOverflowText` and `SErrorMessage` ) would go in `shared/styles/text.ts`
Ah got it! Yes I agree that styles for shared components should be nested within that component folder :+1:
